/app/src/ast.rs:
    1|       |//! Abstract Syntax Tree (AST) for C11 compiler.
    2|       |//!
    3|       |//! This module provides the core AST data structures and APIs for representing
    4|       |//! C11 programs. The AST is designed as a flattened storage system for efficiency,
    5|       |//! with index-based references to child nodes and types.
    6|       |//!
    7|       |//! ## Architecture
    8|       |//!
    9|       |//! The AST is organized into focused submodules for better maintainability:
   10|       |//!
   11|       |//! - [`nodes`]: Node definitions, constructors, and builder patterns for AST nodes
   12|       |//! - [`types`]: Type system representation and utilities for semantic analysis
   13|       |//!
   14|       |//! ## Key Features
   15|       |//!
   16|       |//! - **Flattened Storage**: All AST nodes are stored in contiguous vectors with index-based references
   17|       |//! - **Interior Mutability**: Uses `Cell` for type annotations without requiring mutable AST access
   18|       |//! - **Builder Patterns**: Ergonomic constructors for complex AST nodes
   19|       |//! - **Type System**: Canonical types distinct from syntactic type specifiers
   20|       |//!
   21|       |
   22|       |use std::num::NonZeroU32;
   23|       |
   24|       |/// Represents an interned string using symbol_table crate.
   25|       |/// Alias for GlobalSymbol from symbol_table crate with global feature.
   26|       |pub type NameId = symbol_table::GlobalSymbol;
   27|       |pub type StringId = NameId;
   28|       |
   29|       |use crate::semantic::{QualType, ScopeId, SemanticInfo, SymbolRef, TypeRef, ValueCategory};

  152|  6.98k|            self.current += 1;
  153|  6.98k|            Some(node)

  155|  3.41k|            None

  294|       |    /// Get function name from symbol entry reference
  295|      4|    fn get_function_name(symbol_ref: SymbolRef, symbol_table: Option<&SymbolTable>) -> String {
  296|      4|        if let Some(table) = symbol_table {
  297|      4|            let entry = table.get_symbol(symbol_ref);
  298|      4|            return entry.name.to_string();
  299|      0|        }
  300|      0|        format!("func_{}", symbol_ref.get())
  301|      4|    }
  302|       |
  303|       |    /// Format a DesignatedInitializer for display
  304|      4|    fn format_designated_initializer(init: &DesignatedInitializer, ast: &Ast) -> String {
  305|      4|        let mut result = String::new();
  306|      4|        for designator_ref in init.designator_start.range(init.designator_len) {
  307|      4|            match ast.get_kind(designator_ref) {
  308|      4|                NodeKind::Designator(d) => match d {
  309|      2|                    Designator::FieldName(name) => {
  310|      2|                        result.push_str(&format!(".{}", name));
  311|      2|                    }
  312|      2|                    Designator::ArrayIndex(index) => {
  313|      2|                        result.push_str(&format!("[{}]", index.get()));
  314|      2|                    }
  315|      0|                    Designator::GnuArrayRange(start, end) => {
  316|      0|                        result.push_str(&format!("[{} ... {}]", start.get(), end.get()));
  317|      0|                    }
  318|       |                },
  319|      0|                _ => result.push_str("<invalid designator>"),
  320|       |            }
  321|       |        }
  322|       |
  323|      4|        if init.designator_len > 0 {
  324|      4|            result.push_str(" = ");
  325|      4|        }
                      ^0
  326|       |
  327|      4|        result.push_str(&init.initializer.get().to_string());
  328|      4|        result
  329|      4|    }

  473|       |    /// Dump a single AST node kind

  481|      3|            NodeKind::TranslationUnit(tu_data) => {

   61|       |    GenericSelection(GenericSelectionData),
   62|       |    GenericAssociation(GenericAssociationData),

   64|       |    // --- Statements (Complex statements are separate structs) ---

   70|       |

  514|      1|    ) -> Snippet<'a, annotate_snippets::Annotation<'a>> {
  515|      1|        let source_buffer = source_manager.get_buffer(span.source_id());
  516|      1|        let source = std::str::from_utf8(source_buffer).unwrap_or("");
  517|      1|        let path = source_manager
  518|      1|            .get_file_info(span.source_id())
  519|      1|            .map(|fi| fi.path.to_str().unwrap_or("<unknown>"))
  520|      1|            .unwrap_or("<unknown>");
  521|       |
  522|      1|        let mut snippet = Snippet::source(source).line_start(1).path(path);
  523|       |
  524|      1|        let annotation_kind = AnnotationKind::Primary;
  525|       |
  526|      1|        snippet = snippet.annotation(
  527|      1|            annotation_kind
  528|      1|                .span(span.start().offset() as usize..span.end().offset() as usize)
  529|      1|                .label(message),
  530|       |        );
  531|       |
  532|      1|        snippet
  533|      1|    }

  535|       |    /// Format a single diagnostic with rich source code context
  536|      1|    fn format_diagnostic(&self, diag: &Diagnostic, source_manager: &SourceManager) -> String {
  537|      1|        let renderer = if self.use_colors {
  538|      1|            Renderer::styled().decor_style(DecorStyle::Unicode)
  539|       |        } else {
  540|      0|            Renderer::plain()
  541|       |        };
  542|       |
  543|       |        // If it's a built-in source ID (e.g. command line define), simple print
  544|      1|        if diag.span.is_source_id_builtin() {
  545|      0|            return format!("{}: {}", self.format_location(diag, source_manager), diag.message);
  546|      1|        }
  547|       |
  548|       |        // Primary error snippet
  549|      1|        let snippet = self.create_snippet(diag.span, &diag.message, source_manager);
  550|       |        // Use primary_title instead of title
  551|      1|        let mut group = self.level(diag).primary_title(&diag.message).element(snippet);
  552|       |
  553|      1|        for hint in &diag.hints {
                          ^0
  554|      0|            group = group.element(Level::HELP.message(hint));
  555|      0|        }
  556|       |
  557|       |        // Handle macro expansion history
  558|       |        // We must collect strings first to ensure they live long enough for the snippets
  559|      1|        let mut expansion_history = Vec::new();
  560|      1|        let mut current_id = diag.span.source_id();
  561|       |
  562|      1|        while let Some(file_info) = source_manager.get_file_info(current_id) {
  563|      1|            if let Some(include_loc) = file_info.include_loc {
                                      ^0
  564|       |                // Determine if this is a macro expansion (virtual file) or an include
  565|      0|                let is_macro = file_info.path.to_str().is_some_and(|s| s.starts_with("<macro_"));
  566|      0|                let note_msg = if is_macro {
  567|      0|                    let macro_name = file_info
  568|      0|                        .path
  569|      0|                        .to_str()
  570|      0|                        .unwrap()
  571|      0|                        .trim_start_matches("<macro_")
  572|      0|                        .trim_end_matches('>');
  573|      0|                    format!("expanded from macro '{}'", macro_name)
  574|       |                } else {
  575|      0|                    "included from here".to_string()
  576|       |                };
  577|       |
  578|       |                // For visualization, use a 1-char span at the include/expansion location
  579|      0|                let exp_span = SourceSpan::new_with_length(include_loc.source_id(), include_loc.offset(), 1);
  580|      0|                expansion_history.push((exp_span, note_msg));
  581|       |
  582|      0|                current_id = include_loc.source_id();
  583|       |            } else {
  584|      1|                break;
  585|       |            }
  586|       |        }
  587|       |
  588|      1|        for (span, msg) in &expansion_history {
                           ^0    ^0
  589|      0|            let exp_snippet = self.create_snippet(*span, msg, source_manager);
  590|      0|            group = group.element(exp_snippet);
  591|      0|        }
  592|       |
  593|      1|        let report = &[group];
  594|      1|        renderer.render(report).to_string()
  595|      1|    }
  596|       |
  597|       |    /// Print all diagnostics to stderr
  598|     25|    pub(crate) fn print_diagnostics(&self, diagnostics: &[Diagnostic], source_manager: &SourceManager) {
  599|     26|        for diag in diagnostics {
                          ^1
  600|      1|            let formatted = self.format_diagnostic(diag, source_manager);
  601|      1|            eprintln!("{}", formatted);
  602|      1|        }
  603|     25|    }

   11|      0|                Ok(_) => std::process::exit(0),

   16|       |                    };
   17|      0|                    std::process::exit(1);
   18|       |                }
   19|       |            }
   20|       |        }
   21|      0|        Err(e) => {

    1|       |//! Mid-level Intermediate Representation (MIR) for C11 compiler.
    2|       |//!
    3|       |//! This module provides the MIR data structures and APIs for representing
    4|       |//! C11 programs after semantic analysis. The MIR is designed to be:
    5|       |//! - Typed: All entities have explicit types
    6|       |//! - Explicit: All C semantics are made explicit
    7|       |//! - Cranelift-friendly: Easy to lower to Cranelift IR
    8|       |//! - Non-SSA: Uses basic blocks with explicit control flow
    9|       |
   10|       |use hashbrown::HashMap;

  147|      0|fn f64_to_f128_bytes(val: f64) -> [u8; 16] {
  148|      0|    let bits = val.to_bits();
  149|      0|    let sign = (bits >> 63) & 1;
  150|      0|    let exp = (bits >> 52) & 0x7FF;
  151|      0|    let mant = bits & 0xFFFFFFFFFFFFF;
  152|       |
  153|      0|    let (new_exp, new_mant) = if exp == 0 {
  154|      0|        if mant == 0 {
  155|       |            // Zero
  156|      0|            (0, 0)
  157|       |        } else {
  158|       |            // Subnormal f64 -> Normal f128
  159|       |            // mant is 0.bbbb... (52 bits)
  160|      0|            let lz = mant.leading_zeros() - (64 - 52);
  161|      0|            let shift = lz + 1;
  162|      0|            let normalized_mant = mant << shift;
  163|      0|            let payload = normalized_mant & 0xFFFFFFFFFFFFF; // 52 bits
  164|       |
  165|      0|            let unbiased_exp = -1022 - (shift as i32);
  166|      0|            let biased_exp = unbiased_exp + 16383;
  167|       |
  168|      0|            (biased_exp as u64, (payload as u128) << (112 - 52))
  169|       |        }
  170|      0|    } else if exp == 0x7FF {
  171|       |        // Inf or NaN
  172|      0|        (0x7FFF, (mant as u128) << (112 - 52))
  173|       |    } else {
  174|       |        // Normal
  175|      0|        let unbiased_exp = (exp as i32) - 1023;
  176|      0|        let biased_exp = unbiased_exp + 16383;
  177|      0|        (biased_exp as u64, (mant as u128) << (112 - 52))
  178|       |    };
  179|       |
  180|      0|    let sign_bit = (sign as u128) << 127;
  181|      0|    let exp_bits = (new_exp as u128) << 112;
  182|      0|    let mant_bits = new_mant;
  183|       |
  184|      0|    let result = sign_bit | exp_bits | mant_bits;
  185|      0|    result.to_le_bytes()
  186|      0|}
  187|       |
  188|      8|fn f64_to_x87_bytes(val: f64) -> [u8; 16] {
  189|      8|    let bits = val.to_bits();
  190|      8|    let sign = (bits >> 63) & 1;
  191|      8|    let exp = (bits >> 52) & 0x7FF;
  192|      8|    let mant = bits & 0xFFFFFFFFFFFFF;
  193|       |
  194|      8|    let mut out = [0u8; 16];
  195|       |
  196|      8|    if exp == 0 {
  197|      0|        if mant == 0 {
  198|       |            // Zero
  199|      0|            if sign == 1 {
  200|      0|                out[9] = 0x80;
  201|      0|            }
  202|      0|            return out;
  203|      0|        }
  204|       |
  205|       |        // Subnormal f64
  206|       |        // Calculate leading zeros in the 52-bit mantissa
  207|       |        // 12 zeros because u64 has 64 bits but mant only 52
  208|      0|        let lz = mant.leading_zeros() - 12;
  209|       |
  210|       |        // Shift to make MSB 1 (integer bit for x87)
  211|       |        // We want to put the first '1' at bit 63.
  212|       |        // Currently it is at (51 - lz).
  213|       |        // Shift left by 63 - (51 - lz) = 12 + lz.
  214|      0|        let new_mant = mant << (12 + lz);
  215|       |
  216|       |        // Exponent calculation
  217|       |        // Real exponent of f64 subnormal is -1022.
  218|       |        // We effectively shifted left by (lz + 1) to normalize (because we moved 0.1... to 1.0...)
  219|       |        // So we must subtract (lz + 1) from exponent.
  220|      0|        let real_exp = -1022 - (lz as i32 + 1);
  221|       |
  222|       |        // x87 bias 16383
  223|      0|        let new_exp_biased = (real_exp + 16383) as u16;
  224|       |
  225|      0|        out[0..8].copy_from_slice(&new_mant.to_le_bytes());
  226|      0|        out[8..10].copy_from_slice(&new_exp_biased.to_le_bytes());
  227|      0|        if sign == 1 {
  228|      0|            out[9] |= 0x80;
  229|      0|        }
  230|      0|        return out;
  231|      8|    } else if exp == 0x7FF {
  232|       |        // Inf or NaN
  233|      0|        out[8] = 0xFF;
  234|      0|        out[9] = 0x7F | ((sign as u8) << 7);
  235|       |
  236|      0|        if mant == 0 {
  237|      0|            // Infinity: Integer bit 1, mantissa 0
  238|      0|            out[7] = 0x80;
  239|      0|        } else {
  240|      0|            // NaN: Set integer bit 1
  241|      0|            // f64 mantissa is 52 bits. x87 is 63 bits.
  242|      0|            // Shift left by 11.
  243|      0|            let new_mant = (1u64 << 63) | (mant << 11);
  244|      0|            out[0..8].copy_from_slice(&new_mant.to_le_bytes());
  245|      0|        }
  246|      0|        return out;
  247|      8|    }
  248|       |
  249|       |    // Normal f64
  250|      8|    let unbiased_exp = (exp as i32) - 1023;
  251|      8|    let new_exp = (unbiased_exp + 16383) as u16;
  252|       |
  253|       |    // Explicit integer bit 1 for Normal numbers in x87
  254|      8|    let new_mant = (1u64 << 63) | (mant << 11);
  255|       |
  256|      8|    out[0..8].copy_from_slice(&new_mant.to_le_bytes());
  257|      8|    out[8..10].copy_from_slice(&new_exp.to_le_bytes());
  258|       |
  259|       |    // Sign bit in byte 9, bit 7
  260|      8|    if sign == 1 {
  261|      0|        out[9] |= 0x80;
  262|      8|    }
  263|       |
  264|      8|    out
  265|      8|}

  296|      4|    fields: &[(usize, ConstValueId)],

  299|      4|    ctx: &EmitContext,

  312|      4|            let mut struct_bytes = vec![0u8; struct_size];

  326|      9|                        base_offset + field_offset as u32,
  327|      0|                    )?;
  328|       |
  329|       |                    // Copy the field bytes into the struct buffer
  330|      9|                    let required_size = field_offset + field_bytes.len();

  332|      0|                        struct_bytes.resize(required_size, 0);

  646|       |/// Helper to resolve arguments for a call, handling variadic struct expansion if needed
  647|     25|fn resolve_call_args(

  651|     25|    ctx: &mut BodyEmitContext,

  657|     25|    let mut sig_idx = 0;
  658|     25|    let mut xmm_used = 0;
  659|       |

  661|       |    // But here we iterate all args. We need to distinguish fixed params.
  662|       |    // We can assume first `fixed_param_count` args match `sig`'s first params,
  663|       |    // but `sig` might have split params.

  670|     28|            if is_xmm_argument(mir_type) {
  671|      0|                xmm_used += 1;
  672|     28|            }
  673|      0|        }
  674|       |    }
  675|       |
  676|     63|    for (arg_idx, arg) in args.iter().enumerate() {
                                        ^25  ^25    ^25
  677|     63|        if sig_idx >= sig.params.len() {
  678|      0|            break;

  682|     63|        let arg_type_id = get_operand_type_id(arg, ctx.mir).ok();
  683|       |
  684|       |        // Check for struct packing in fixed parameters
  685|     63|        if arg_idx < fixed_param_count
  686|     28|            && let Some(type_id) = arg_type_id
  687|     28|            && let Some(count) = get_struct_packing(ctx.mir.get_type(type_id), ctx.mir)
                                      ^2

 1341|       |/// Helper function to resolve a MIR place to a Cranelift value
 1342|    120|fn resolve_place(place: &Place, ctx: &mut BodyEmitContext, expected_type: Type) -> Result<Value, String> {
 1343|    120|    match place {
 1344|     89|        Place::Local(local_id) => {
 1345|       |            // A local place is resolved by loading from its stack slot
 1346|     89|            if let Some(stack_slot) = ctx.stack_slots.get(local_id) {
 1347|     89|                Ok(ctx.builder.ins().stack_load(expected_type, *stack_slot, 0))
 1348|       |            } else {
 1349|      0|                Err(format!("Stack slot not found for local {}", local_id.get()))
 1350|       |            }
 1351|       |        }
 1352|      2|        Place::Global(_global_id) => {
 1353|       |            // First, get the memory address of the global.
 1354|      2|            let addr = resolve_place_to_addr(place, ctx)?;
                                                                      ^0
 1355|       |
 1356|       |            // Then, load the value from that address.
 1357|      2|            Ok(ctx.builder.ins().load(expected_type, MemFlags::new(), addr, 0))
 1358|       |        }
 1359|      0|        Place::Deref(operand) => {
 1360|       |            // The address is the value of the operand, so we load from that value
 1361|      0|            let addr = resolve_operand(operand, ctx, types::I64)?;
 1362|      0|            Ok(ctx.builder.ins().load(expected_type, MemFlags::new(), addr, 0))
 1363|       |        }

 1365|       |            // Get the address of the struct field
 1366|     18|            let addr = resolve_place_to_addr(&Place::StructField(base_place.clone(), *field_index), ctx)?;
                                                                                                                      ^0
 1367|     18|            Ok(ctx.builder.ins().load(expected_type, MemFlags::new(), addr, 0))
 1368|       |        }
 1369|     11|        Place::ArrayIndex(base_place, index_operand) => {
 1370|       |            // Get the address of the array element
 1371|     11|            let addr = resolve_place_to_addr(&Place::ArrayIndex(base_place.clone(), index_operand.clone()), ctx)?;

 1507|       |/// Helper function to resolve a MIR place to a memory address
 1508|    129|fn resolve_place_to_addr(place: &Place, ctx: &mut BodyEmitContext) -> Result<Value, String> {
 1509|    129|    match place {
 1510|     70|        Place::Local(local_id) => {

 1518|     16|            let global = ctx.mir.get_global(*global_id);

                                           ^0      ^0                                        ^0

 1530|       |            // Use I64 for addresses

 1532|       |        }

 1535|      4|            resolve_operand(operand, ctx, types::I64)

 2264|    163|    match terminator {

                                                                               ^0
 2276|       |
 2277|     36|            let then_cl_block = ctx
 2278|     36|                .clif_blocks
 2279|     36|                .get(then_bb)

 2282|     36|                .clif_blocks

 2284|     36|                .ok_or_else(|| format!("'Else' block {} not found", else_bb.get()))?;

 2321|    274|fn setup_signature(
 2322|    274|    func: &MirFunction,
 2323|    274|    mir: &MirProgram,
 2324|    274|    func_ctx: &mut Signature,
 2325|    274|) -> Result<(Option<Type>, Vec<Type>), String> {
 2326|       |    // Set up function signature using the actual return type from MIR
 2327|    274|    func_ctx.params.clear();
 2328|       |
 2329|       |    // Get the return type from MIR and convert to Cranelift type

/app/src/mir/validation.rs:
    1|       |//! MIR Validation Pass
    2|       |//!
    3|       |//! This module implements a validation pass that ensures MIR is well-formed
    4|       |//! and ready for code generation. The validation pass checks:
    5|       |//! - All locals have types
    6|       |//! - All blocks end with a Terminator
    7|       |//! - No illegal operations remain
    8|       |//! - MIR is Cranelift-safe
    9|       |
   10|       |use crate::{
   11|       |    ast::NameId,
   12|       |    mir::{
   13|       |        BinaryFloatOp, BinaryIntOp, CallTarget, ConstValue, ConstValueId, ConstValueKind, GlobalId, LocalId,
   14|       |        MirBlockId, MirFunction, MirFunctionId, MirFunctionKind, MirProgram, MirStmt, MirStmtId, MirType, Operand,
   15|       |        Place, Rvalue, Terminator, TypeId, UnaryFloatOp, UnaryIntOp,
   16|       |    },
   17|       |};
   18|       |
   19|       |/// MIR Validation Error
   20|       |#[derive(Debug, PartialEq, Clone)]
   21|       |pub enum ValidationError {
   22|       |    /// Local variable is missing a type
   23|       |    LocalMissingType(LocalId),
   24|       |    /// Illegal operation found in MIR
   25|       |    IllegalOperation(String),
   26|       |    /// Type not found in type table
   27|       |    TypeNotFound(TypeId),
   28|       |    /// Local not found in local table
   29|       |    LocalNotFound(LocalId),
   30|       |    /// Global not found in global table
   31|       |    GlobalNotFound(GlobalId),
   32|       |    /// Function not found in function table
   33|       |    FunctionNotFound(MirFunctionId),
   34|       |    /// Block not found in block table
   35|       |    BlockNotFound(MirBlockId),
   36|       |    /// Statement not found in statement table
   37|       |    StatementNotFound(MirStmtId),
   38|       |    /// Invalid pointer arithmetic operation
   39|       |    InvalidPointerArithmetic,
   40|       |    /// Invalid cast operation
   41|       |    InvalidCast(TypeId, TypeId),
   42|       |    /// Function call argument type mismatch
   43|       |    FunctionCallArgTypeMismatch {
   44|       |        func_name: NameId,
   45|       |        arg_index: usize,
   46|       |        expected_type: TypeId,
   47|       |        actual_type: TypeId,
   48|       |    },
   49|       |    /// Constant value is out of range for its type
   50|       |    ConstantValueOutOfRange {
   51|       |        const_id: ConstValueId,
   52|       |        value: i64,
   53|       |        type_id: TypeId,
   54|       |    },
   55|       |}
   56|       |
   57|       |impl std::fmt::Display for ValidationError {
   58|      0|    fn fmt(&self, f: &mut std::fmt::Formatter<'_>) -> std::fmt::Result {

  330|       |/// Parse expression for initializer (stops at commas that separate declarators)

/app/src/parser/declarator.rs:
    1|       |//! Declarator parsing module
    2|       |//!
    3|       |//! This module handles the parsing of C declarators, which are the most complex
    4|       |//! part of C's declaration syntax. Declarators can be nested and include pointers,
    5|       |//! arrays, and functions.
    6|       |
    7|       |use crate::diagnostic::ParseError;
    8|       |use crate::parser::declaration_core::parse_declaration_specifiers;
    9|       |use crate::parser::{Token, TokenKind};
   10|       |use crate::{ast::*, semantic::TypeQualifiers};
   11|       |use log::debug;
   12|       |use thin_vec::{ThinVec, thin_vec};
   13|       |
   14|       |use super::Parser;
   15|       |
   16|       |/// Helper enum for reconstructing complex declarators
   17|       |#[derive(Debug)]
   18|       |enum DeclaratorComponent {
   19|       |    Pointer(TypeQualifiers),
   20|       |}
   21|       |
   22|       |/// Look ahead past a GCC-style `__attribute__((...))` construct without consuming tokens.
   23|       |/// Returns the token immediately following the attribute if the structure is valid, or None.
   24|       |///
   25|       |/// Expects: Attribute (( ... ))
   26|      2|fn peek_past_attribute(parser: &Parser, mut start_offset: u32) -> Option<Token> {
   27|       |    // start_offset points to Attribute token
   28|       |    // Attribute should be followed by ((...))
   29|      2|    start_offset += 1;
   30|       |
   31|       |    // Expect ((
   32|      2|    let t1 = parser.peek_token(start_offset)?;
                                                          ^0
   33|      2|    if t1.kind != TokenKind::LeftParen {
   34|      0|        return None;
   35|      2|    }
   36|      2|    start_offset += 1;
   37|       |
   38|      2|    let t2 = parser.peek_token(start_offset)?;
                                                          ^0
   39|      2|    if t2.kind != TokenKind::LeftParen {
   40|      0|        return None;
   41|      2|    }
   42|      2|    start_offset += 1;

  331|       |/// Check if a symbol represents a C11 keyword.

  430|  7.00k|            PPTokenKind::Identifier(symbol) => {
  431|       |                // Check if it's a keyword
  432|  7.00k|                is_keyword(symbol).unwrap_or(TokenKind::Identifier(symbol))
  433|       |            }

  461|       |    /// Get all tokens from the stream
  462|    638|    pub fn tokenize_all(&mut self) -> Vec<Token> {
  463|       |        // Bolt : Pre-allocate the tokens vector with the capacity of the preprocessor tokens.
  464|       |        // This is a reasonable estimate that reduces the number of reallocations,
  465|       |        // as the number of lexical tokens is usually similar to the number of preprocessor tokens.
  466|    638|        let mut tokens = Vec::with_capacity(self.tokens.len());
  467|    638|        let mut current_token_iter = self.tokens.iter().peekable();
  468|       |
  469|  16.2k|        while let Some(pptoken) = current_token_iter.next() {
  470|  16.2k|            if let PPTokenKind::StringLiteral(symbol) = pptoken.kind {
                                                            ^112
  471|       |                //  Bolt: Optimized string literal handling.
  472|       |                // This introduces a fast path for single string literals, which are the
  473|       |                // most common case. By peeking ahead, we avoid the overhead of the
  474|       |                // two-pass concatenation logic unless it's actually needed. This
  475|       |                // reduces overhead and improves lexer performance.
  476|       |
  477|       |                // --- Fast path for single string literals ---
  478|    106|                if !matches!(
  479|    112|                    current_token_iter.peek(),
  480|       |                    Some(PPToken {
  481|       |                        kind: PPTokenKind::StringLiteral(_),
  482|       |                        ..
  483|       |                    })
  484|       |                ) {
  485|    106|                    tokens.push(Token {
  486|    106|                        kind: self.classify_token(pptoken), // Handles quote stripping
  487|    106|                        span: SourceSpan::new_with_length(
  488|    106|                            pptoken.location.source_id(),
  489|    106|                            pptoken.location.offset(),
  490|    106|                            pptoken.length as u32,
  491|    106|                        ),
  492|    106|                    });
  493|    106|                    continue;
  494|      6|                }
  495|       |
  496|       |                // --- Slow path: Concatenate adjacent string literals ---
  497|      6|                let start_span = SourceSpan::new_with_length(
  498|      6|                    pptoken.location.source_id(),
  499|      6|                    pptoken.location.offset(),
  500|      6|                    pptoken.length as u32,
  501|       |                );
  502|      6|                let mut final_span = start_span;
  503|       |
  504|       |                // --- Phase 1: Calculate total size and find last span ---
  505|      6|                let mut total_size = Self::extract_string_content(&symbol).unwrap_or("").len();
  506|      6|                let mut adjacent_literals = 0;
  507|      6|                let next_token_idx = self.tokens.len() - current_token_iter.len();
  508|       |
  509|     15|                while let Some(next_pptoken) = self.tokens.get(next_token_idx + adjacent_literals) {
  510|     15|                    if let PPTokenKind::StringLiteral(next_symbol) = next_pptoken.kind {
                                                                    ^9
  511|      9|                        total_size += Self::extract_string_content(&next_symbol).unwrap_or("").len();
  512|      9|                        final_span = SourceSpan::new_with_length(
  513|      9|                            next_pptoken.location.source_id(),
  514|      9|                            next_pptoken.location.offset(),
  515|      9|                            next_pptoken.length as u32,
  516|      9|                        );
  517|      9|                        adjacent_literals += 1;
  518|      9|                    } else {
  519|      6|                        break;
  520|       |                    }
  521|       |                }
  522|       |
  523|       |                // --- Phase 2: Allocate and append ---
  524|      6|                let mut content = String::with_capacity(total_size);
  525|      6|                if let Some(s_content) = Self::extract_string_content(&symbol) {
  526|      6|                    literal_parsing::unescape_string_into(s_content, &mut content);
  527|      6|                }
                              ^0
  528|       |
  529|      6|                for _ in 0..adjacent_literals {
  530|      9|                    let consumed_pptoken = current_token_iter.next().unwrap();
  531|      9|                    if let PPTokenKind::StringLiteral(next_symbol) = consumed_pptoken.kind
  532|      9|                        && let Some(s_content) = Self::extract_string_content(&next_symbol)
  533|      9|                    {
  534|      9|                        literal_parsing::unescape_string_into(s_content, &mut content);
  535|      9|                    }
                                  ^0
  536|       |                }
  537|       |
  538|      6|                tokens.push(Token {
  539|      6|                    kind: TokenKind::StringLiteral(StringId::new(content)),
  540|      6|                    span: start_span.merge(final_span),
  541|      6|                });
  542|      6|                continue;
  543|  16.1k|            }
  544|       |
  545|       |            // For all other tokens, process normally
  546|  16.1k|            let token = Token {
  547|  16.1k|                kind: self.classify_token(pptoken),
  548|  16.1k|                span: SourceSpan::new_with_length(
  549|  16.1k|                    pptoken.location.source_id(),
  550|  16.1k|                    pptoken.location.offset(),
  551|  16.1k|                    pptoken.length as u32,
  552|  16.1k|                ),
  553|  16.1k|            };
  554|       |
  555|  16.1k|            let is_eof = matches!(token.kind, TokenKind::EndOfFile);
                                       ^15.4k
  556|  16.1k|            tokens.push(token);
  557|  16.1k|            if is_eof {
  558|    638|                break;
  559|  15.4k|            }
  560|       |        }
  561|       |
  562|    638|        tokens
  563|    638|    }

  715|       |    /// Evaluate a conditional expression (simplified - handle defined and basic arithmetic)
  716|     31|    fn evaluate_conditional_expression(&mut self, tokens: Vec<PPToken>) -> Result<bool, PPError> {
  717|       |        // Bolt : Removed redundant filtering of Eod tokens and a buggy optimization.
  718|       |        // parse_conditional_expression already ensures no Eod tokens are present.
  719|       |        // This avoids two allocations and two full clones of the token list.
  720|       |        // The buggy 'defined' optimization was also removed as it incorrectly
  721|       |        // returned early for complex expressions like '#if defined(FOO) && 0'.
  722|       |        // Bolt : Optimized to take tokens by value, avoiding a redundant `to_vec()` clone.
  723|     31|        if tokens.is_empty() {
  724|       |            // For empty expressions, treat as false
  725|      0|            return Ok(false);
  726|     31|        }
  727|       |
  728|       |        // First, expand macros in the expression
  729|     31|        let mut expanded_tokens = tokens;
  730|     31|        match self.expand_tokens(&mut expanded_tokens, true) {
  731|     31|            Ok(_) => {}
  732|      0|            Err(_e) => {
  733|       |                // If macro expansion fails, emit diagnostic and treat as false
  734|      0|                let span = if !expanded_tokens.is_empty() {
  735|      0|                    SourceSpan::new(expanded_tokens[0].location, expanded_tokens.last().unwrap().location)
  736|       |                } else {
  737|      0|                    let loc = self.get_current_location();
  738|      0|                    SourceSpan::new(loc, loc)
  739|       |                };
  740|      0|                self.report_diagnostic_simple(
  741|      0|                    DiagnosticLevel::Warning,
  742|      0|                    "Failed to expand macros in conditional expression".to_string(),
  743|      0|                    span,
  744|      0|                    Some("macro_expansion_failed".to_string()),
  745|      0|                    vec!["Expression will be treated as false".to_string()],
  746|       |                );
  747|      0|                return Ok(false);
  748|       |            }
  749|       |        }
  750|       |
  751|       |        // Evaluate arithmetic expression with better error handling
  752|     31|        self.evaluate_arithmetic_expression(&expanded_tokens)
  753|     31|    }
  754|       |
  755|       |    /// Evaluate a simple arithmetic expression for #if/#elif
  756|     31|    fn evaluate_arithmetic_expression(&mut self, tokens: &[PPToken]) -> Result<bool, PPError> {
  757|     31|        if tokens.is_empty() {

 1707|      1|    fn read_directive_message(&mut self) -> String {
 1708|       |        // Optimization: Avoid multiple small allocations by calculating final string size first.
 1709|       |        // This follows the two-pass approach:
 1710|       |        // 1. Collect tokens for the line.
 1711|       |        // 2. Calculate the total length required for the string.
 1712|       |        // 3. Allocate a single string with the required capacity.
 1713|       |        // 4. Populate the string in a second pass over the tokens.
 1714|      1|        let mut tokens = Vec::new();
 1715|      2|        while let Some(token) = self.lex_token() {
 1716|      2|            if token.kind == PPTokenKind::Eod {
 1717|      1|                break;
 1718|      1|            }
 1719|      1|            tokens.push(token);
 1720|       |        }
 1721|       |
 1722|      1|        if tokens.is_empty() {
 1723|      0|            return String::new();
 1724|      1|        }
 1725|       |
 1726|       |        // Calculate total length
 1727|      1|        let mut total_len = 0;
 1728|      1|        for (i, token) in tokens.iter().enumerate() {
 1729|      1|            total_len += token.length as usize;
 1730|      1|            if i > 0 {
 1731|      0|                total_len += 1; // For the space separator
 1732|      1|            }
 1733|       |        }
 1734|       |
 1735|       |        // Allocate and build the string
 1736|      1|        let mut result = String::with_capacity(total_len);
 1737|      1|        for (i, token) in tokens.iter().enumerate() {
 1738|      1|            if i > 0 {
 1739|      0|                result.push(' ');
 1740|      1|            }
 1741|      1|            let buffer = self.sm.get_buffer(token.location.source_id());
 1742|      1|            let start = token.location.offset() as usize;
 1743|      1|            let end = start + token.length as usize;
 1744|      1|            if end <= buffer.len() {
 1745|      1|                // This is safe because the lexer guarantees tokens are valid UTF-8.
 1746|      1|                let text = unsafe { std::str::from_utf8_unchecked(&buffer[start..end]) };
 1747|      1|                result.push_str(text);
 1748|      1|            }
                          ^0
 1749|       |        }
 1750|       |
 1751|      1|        result
 1752|      1|    }

 1798|       |    /// Helper to convert tokens to their string representation
 1799|    123|    fn tokens_to_string(&self, tokens: &[PPToken]) -> String {

                          ^123       ^123    ^123   ^123   ^123                       ^123

 1807|    123|        let mut result = String::with_capacity(total_len);
 1808|       |
 1809|       |        // 3. Populate the string.
 1810|    663|        for token in tokens {
                          ^540
 1811|    540|            result.push_str(token.get_text());
 1812|    540|        }
 1813|    123|        result
 1814|    123|    }

  188|      7|    fn can_fall_through(&self, node_ref: NodeRef) -> bool {

  740|    211|    pub(crate) fn emit_assignment(&mut self, place: Place, operand: Operand) {
  741|    211|        if self.mir_builder.current_block_has_terminator() {
  742|      0|            return;
  743|    211|        }
  744|       |
  745|       |        // Avoid identity assignments like %x = %x
  746|    211|        if let Operand::Copy(box_place) = &operand

  419|     72|    fn lower_binary_arithmetic_logic(

  494|      4|    pub(crate) fn emit_bool_normalization(
  495|      4|        &mut self,
  496|      4|        value_op: Operand,
  497|      4|        result_place: Place,
  498|      4|        merge_block: crate::mir::MirBlockId,
  499|      4|    ) {
  500|      4|        let true_block = self.mir_builder.create_block();
  501|      4|        let false_block = self.mir_builder.create_block();
  502|       |
  503|      4|        self.mir_builder
  504|      4|            .set_terminator(Terminator::If(value_op, true_block, false_block));
  505|       |
  506|      4|        self.mir_builder.set_current_block(true_block);
  507|      4|        let one_op = self.create_int_operand(1);
  508|      4|        self.mir_builder
  509|      4|            .add_statement(MirStmt::Assign(result_place.clone(), Rvalue::Use(one_op)));
  510|      4|        self.mir_builder.set_terminator(Terminator::Goto(merge_block));
  511|       |
  512|      4|        self.mir_builder.set_current_block(false_block);
  513|      4|        let zero_op = self.create_int_operand(0);
  514|      4|        self.mir_builder
  515|      4|            .add_statement(MirStmt::Assign(result_place.clone(), Rvalue::Use(zero_op)));
  516|      4|        self.mir_builder.set_terminator(Terminator::Goto(merge_block));
  517|      4|    }

  519|      4|    pub(crate) fn lower_logical_op(
  520|      4|        &mut self,
  521|      4|        op: &BinaryOp,
  522|      4|        left_ref: NodeRef,
  523|      4|        right_ref: NodeRef,
  524|      4|        mir_ty: TypeId,
  525|      4|    ) -> Operand {
  526|       |        // Short-circuiting logic for && and ||
  527|      4|        let (_res_local, res_place) = self.create_temp_local(mir_ty);
  528|       |
  529|      4|        let eval_rhs_block = self.mir_builder.create_block();
  530|      4|        let merge_block = self.mir_builder.create_block();
  531|      4|        let short_circuit_block = self.mir_builder.create_block();
  532|       |
  533|       |        // 1. Evaluate LHS
  534|      4|        let lhs_op = self.lower_condition(left_ref);
  535|       |
  536|       |        // Pre-create constants to avoid double borrow
  537|      4|        let zero_op = self.create_int_operand(0);
  538|      4|        let one_op = self.create_int_operand(1);
  539|       |
  540|      4|        let (short_circuit_val, true_target, false_target) = match op {
  541|      0|            BinaryOp::LogicAnd => (zero_op.clone(), eval_rhs_block, short_circuit_block),
  542|      4|            BinaryOp::LogicOr => (one_op.clone(), short_circuit_block, eval_rhs_block),
  543|      0|            _ => unreachable!(),
  544|       |        };
  545|       |
  546|       |        // if lhs { goto true_target } else { goto false_target }
  547|      4|        self.mir_builder
  548|      4|            .set_terminator(Terminator::If(lhs_op, true_target, false_target));
  549|       |
  550|       |        // Short circuit case
  551|      4|        self.mir_builder.set_current_block(short_circuit_block);
  552|      4|        self.mir_builder
  553|      4|            .add_statement(MirStmt::Assign(res_place.clone(), Rvalue::Use(short_circuit_val)));
  554|      4|        self.mir_builder.set_terminator(Terminator::Goto(merge_block));
  555|       |
  556|       |        // 2. Evaluate RHS
  557|      4|        self.mir_builder.set_current_block(eval_rhs_block);
  558|      4|        let rhs_val = self.lower_condition(right_ref);
  559|       |
  560|      4|        self.emit_bool_normalization(rhs_val, res_place.clone(), merge_block);
  561|       |
  562|       |        // Merge
  563|      4|        self.mir_builder.set_current_block(merge_block);
  564|      4|        self.current_block = Some(merge_block);
  565|       |
  566|      4|        Operand::Copy(Box::new(res_place))
  567|      4|    }

  759|     60|    pub(crate) fn find_member_path(&self, record_ty: semantic::TypeRef, field_name: ast::NameId) -> Option<Vec<usize>> {

  827|     14|    pub(crate) fn lower_inc_dec_expression(
  828|     14|        &mut self,
  829|     14|        operand_ref: NodeRef,
  830|     14|        is_inc: bool,
  831|     14|        is_post: bool,
  832|     14|        need_value: bool,
  833|     14|    ) -> Operand {
  834|     14|        let operand = self.lower_expression(operand_ref, true);
  835|     14|        let operand_ty = self.ast.get_resolved_type(operand_ref).unwrap();
  836|     14|        let mir_ty = self.lower_qual_type(operand_ty);
  837|       |
  838|     14|        if self.ast.get_value_category(operand_ref) != Some(ValueCategory::LValue) {
  839|      0|            panic!("Inc/Dec operand must be an lvalue");
  840|     14|        }
  841|       |
  842|     14|        let place = if let Operand::Copy(place) = operand.clone() {
  843|     14|            place
  844|       |        } else {
  845|      0|            panic!("Inc/Dec operand is not a place");
  846|       |        };
  847|       |
  848|       |        // If it's post-inc/dec and we need the value, save the old value
  849|     14|        let old_value = if is_post && need_value {
                                                    ^12
  850|      9|            let rval = Rvalue::Use(operand.clone());
  851|      9|            let (_, temp_place) = self.create_temp_local_with_assignment(rval, mir_ty);
  852|      9|            Some(Operand::Copy(Box::new(temp_place)))
  853|       |        } else {
  854|      5|            None
  855|       |        };
  856|       |
  857|       |        // Determine MIR operation and Rvalue
  858|     14|        let rval = self.create_inc_dec_rvalue(operand.clone(), operand_ty, is_inc);
  859|       |
  860|       |        // Perform the assignment
  861|     14|        if is_post && !need_value {
                                    ^12
  862|      3|            // Optimization: assign directly to place if old value not needed
  863|      3|            self.mir_builder.add_statement(MirStmt::Assign(*place.clone(), rval));
  864|      3|        } else {
  865|       |            // If we needed old value (is_post), or if it is pre-inc (need new value),
  866|       |            // we compute to a temp first to ensure correctness and return the right value.
  867|     11|            let (_, new_place) = self.create_temp_local_with_assignment(rval, mir_ty);
  868|     11|            self.emit_assignment(*place.clone(), Operand::Copy(Box::new(new_place.clone())));
  869|       |
  870|     11|            if !is_post {
  871|       |                // Pre-inc: return the new value
  872|      2|                return Operand::Copy(Box::new(new_place));
  873|      9|            }
  874|       |        }
  875|       |
  876|     12|        if is_post {
  877|     12|            if need_value {
  878|      9|                old_value.unwrap()
  879|       |            } else {
  880|      3|                self.create_int_operand(0)
  881|       |            }
  882|       |        } else {
  883|       |            // Pre-inc: we already returned inside the block above.
  884|       |            // RE-FETCH from place as a fallback (should not be reached)
  885|      0|            Operand::Copy(place)
  886|       |        }
  887|     14|    }
  888|       |
  889|     14|    pub(crate) fn create_inc_dec_rvalue(&mut self, operand: Operand, operand_ty: QualType, is_inc: bool) -> Rvalue {
  890|     14|        let one_const = self.create_int_operand(1);
  891|     14|        let minus_one_const = self.create_int_operand(-1);
  892|       |
  893|     14|        if operand_ty.is_pointer() {
  894|      4|            let op = if is_inc { BinaryOp::Add } else { BinaryOp::Sub };
                                                                      ^0
  895|      4|            self.create_pointer_arithmetic_rvalue(operand, one_const, op)
  896|       |        } else {
  897|       |            // For Integers: Add(delta) (Note: we use Add with negative delta for decrement
  898|       |            // to support proper wrapping arithmetic and fix previous bugs)
  899|     10|            let rhs = if is_inc { one_const } else { minus_one_const };
                                                ^5                 ^5
  900|     10|            Rvalue::BinaryIntOp(BinaryIntOp::Add, operand, rhs)
  901|       |        }
  902|     14|    }
  903|       |
  904|      6|    pub(crate) fn create_pointer_arithmetic_rvalue(&mut self, lhs: Operand, rhs: Operand, op: BinaryOp) -> Rvalue {
  905|      6|        match op {
  906|      5|            BinaryOp::Add => Rvalue::PtrAdd(lhs, rhs),
  907|      1|            BinaryOp::Sub => Rvalue::PtrSub(lhs, rhs),
  908|      0|            _ => panic!("Invalid pointer arithmetic op"),
  909|       |        }
  910|      6|    }

  941|     10|    pub(crate) fn lower_atomic_op(
  942|     10|        &mut self,
  943|     10|        op: AtomicOp,

  945|     10|        args_len: u16,

  950|       |
  951|     10|        match op {
  952|       |            AtomicOp::LoadN => {
  953|      1|                let ptr = args[0].clone();
  954|       |                // args[1] is memorder, ignored
  955|      1|                let rval = Rvalue::AtomicLoad(ptr, order);
  956|      1|                self.emit_rvalue_to_operand(rval, mir_ty)
  957|       |            }

  959|      1|                let ptr = args[0].clone();
  960|      1|                let val = args[1].clone();
  961|       |                // args[2] is memorder, ignored
  962|      1|                self.mir_builder.add_statement(MirStmt::AtomicStore(ptr, val, order));
  963|      1|                self.create_dummy_operand()
  964|       |            }
  965|       |            AtomicOp::ExchangeN => {
  966|      1|                let ptr = args[0].clone();
  967|      1|                let val = args[1].clone();
  968|       |                // args[2] is memorder, ignored
  969|      1|                let rval = Rvalue::AtomicExchange(ptr, val, order);
  970|      1|                self.emit_rvalue_to_operand(rval, mir_ty)
  971|       |            }
  972|      2|            AtomicOp::CompareExchangeN => self.lower_atomic_cmpxchg(&args, order, mir_ty),
  973|      1|            AtomicOp::FetchAdd => self.lower_atomic_fetch_op(BinaryIntOp::Add, &args, order, mir_ty),
  974|      1|            AtomicOp::FetchSub => self.lower_atomic_fetch_op(BinaryIntOp::Sub, &args, order, mir_ty),
  975|      1|            AtomicOp::FetchAnd => self.lower_atomic_fetch_op(BinaryIntOp::BitAnd, &args, order, mir_ty),
  976|      1|            AtomicOp::FetchOr => self.lower_atomic_fetch_op(BinaryIntOp::BitOr, &args, order, mir_ty),
  977|      1|            AtomicOp::FetchXor => self.lower_atomic_fetch_op(BinaryIntOp::BitXor, &args, order, mir_ty),
  978|       |        }
  979|     10|    }

  988|      2|    fn lower_atomic_cmpxchg(&mut self, args: &[Operand], order: AtomicMemOrder, mir_ty: TypeId) -> Operand {
  989|      2|        let ptr = args[0].clone();
  990|      2|        let expected_ptr = args[1].clone();
  991|      2|        let desired = args[2].clone();
  992|       |        // args[3] weak, args[4] success, args[5] failure (ignored side effects were handled by lowering args)
  993|       |
  994|      2|        let expected_place = match expected_ptr {
  995|      1|            Operand::Copy(p) => Place::Deref(Box::new(Operand::Copy(p))),
  996|      1|            _ => Place::Deref(Box::new(expected_ptr)),
  997|       |        };

  999|       |
 1000|      2|        let weak = false;
 1001|      2|        let cas_rval = Rvalue::AtomicCompareExchange(ptr, expected_val_op.clone(), desired.clone(), weak, order, order);
 1002|       |
 1003|      2|        let val_ty = self.get_operand_type(&desired);
 1004|      2|        let (_, old_val_place) = self.create_temp_local_with_assignment(cas_rval, val_ty);
 1005|      2|        let old_val = Operand::Copy(Box::new(old_val_place));
 1006|       |
 1007|      2|        let mir_type_info = self.mir_builder.get_type(val_ty);
 1008|      2|        let cmp_rval = if mir_type_info.is_float() {
 1009|      0|            Rvalue::BinaryFloatOp(crate::mir::BinaryFloatOp::Eq, old_val.clone(), expected_val_op)
 1010|       |        } else {
 1011|      2|            Rvalue::BinaryIntOp(BinaryIntOp::Eq, old_val.clone(), expected_val_op)
 1012|       |        };
 1013|       |
 1014|      2|        let (_, success_place) = self.create_temp_local_with_assignment(cmp_rval, mir_ty);
 1015|      2|        let success_op = Operand::Copy(Box::new(success_place));
 1016|       |

 1018|      2|        let end_block = self.mir_builder.create_block();
 1019|       |
 1020|      2|        self.mir_builder
 1021|      2|            .set_terminator(Terminator::If(success_op.clone(), end_block, update_block));
 1022|       |
 1023|      2|        self.mir_builder.set_current_block(update_block);
 1024|      2|        self.mir_builder
 1025|      2|            .add_statement(MirStmt::Assign(expected_place, Rvalue::Use(old_val)));
 1026|      2|        self.mir_builder.set_terminator(Terminator::Goto(end_block));
 1027|       |
 1028|      2|        self.mir_builder.set_current_block(end_block);

  987|       |/// Validate specifier combinations for semantic correctness
  988|  2.00k|fn validate_specifier_combinations(info: &DeclSpecInfo, ctx: &mut LowerCtx, span: SourceSpan) {

  995|  2.00k|    if info.alignment.is_some() && info.storage == Some(StorageClass::Register) {

  997|      1|            context: "register object".to_string(),

  999|      1|        });

   29|     80|pub(crate) fn map_ast_binary_op_to_mir_int(ast_op: &BinaryOp) -> BinaryIntOp {
   30|     80|    let op = ast_op.without_assignment().unwrap_or(*ast_op);
   31|     80|    match op {
   32|     13|        BinaryOp::Add => BinaryIntOp::Add,
   33|     12|        BinaryOp::Sub => BinaryIntOp::Sub,
   34|      2|        BinaryOp::Mul => BinaryIntOp::Mul,
   35|      2|        BinaryOp::Div => BinaryIntOp::Div,
   36|      3|        BinaryOp::Mod => BinaryIntOp::Mod,
   37|      2|        BinaryOp::BitAnd => BinaryIntOp::BitAnd,
   38|      1|        BinaryOp::BitOr => BinaryIntOp::BitOr,
   39|      1|        BinaryOp::BitXor => BinaryIntOp::BitXor,
   40|      1|        BinaryOp::LShift => BinaryIntOp::LShift,
   41|      1|        BinaryOp::RShift => BinaryIntOp::RShift,
   42|      6|        BinaryOp::Equal => BinaryIntOp::Eq,
   43|     28|        BinaryOp::NotEqual => BinaryIntOp::Ne,
   44|      3|        BinaryOp::Less => BinaryIntOp::Lt,
   45|      1|        BinaryOp::LessEqual => BinaryIntOp::Le,
   46|      3|        BinaryOp::Greater => BinaryIntOp::Gt,
   47|      1|        BinaryOp::GreaterEqual => BinaryIntOp::Ge,
   48|       |        // Logic ops are handled separately (short-circuit)
   49|      0|        BinaryOp::LogicAnd | BinaryOp::LogicOr => panic!("Logic ops should be handled separately"),
   50|      0|        BinaryOp::Comma => panic!("Comma op should be handled separately"), // Comma usually handled in expression lowering
   51|      0|        _ => panic!("Unsupported integer binary operator: {:?}", ast_op),
   52|       |    }

  479|       |    /// Merge a new symbol entry with an existing one in the global scope.
  480|       |    /// This implements C11 6.9.2 for handling tentative definitions, extern declarations, and actual definitions.
  481|    691|    fn merge_global_symbol(&mut self, name: NameId, mut new_entry: Symbol) -> Result<SymbolRef, SymbolTableError> {
  482|    691|        let global_scope = ScopeId::GLOBAL;
  483|       |
  484|       |        // Check if symbol already exists in global scope
  485|    691|        if let Some(existing_ref) = self.fetch(name, global_scope, Namespace::Ordinary) {
                                  ^29
  486|     29|            let existing = self.get_symbol_mut(existing_ref);
  487|       |
  488|       |            // Verify kinds match
  489|     29|            match (&existing.kind, &new_entry.kind) {
  490|      9|                (SymbolKind::Variable { .. }, SymbolKind::Variable { .. }) => {}
  491|     18|                (SymbolKind::Function { .. }, SymbolKind::Function { .. }) => {}
  492|       |                _ => {
  493|       |                    // Mismatched kinds
  494|      2|                    debug!("Symbol '{}' redefinition: different kinds", name);
                                         ^0
  495|      2|                    return Err(SymbolTableError::InvalidRedefinition {
  496|      2|                        name,
  497|      2|                        existing: existing_ref,
  498|      2|                    });
  499|       |                }
  500|       |            }
  501|       |
  502|       |            // Check alignment compatibility (Variables only)
  503|       |            if let SymbolKind::Variable {
  504|      9|                alignment: new_align, ..
  505|     27|            } = &new_entry.kind
  506|       |                && let SymbolKind::Variable {
  507|      9|                    alignment: existing_align,
  508|       |                    ..
  509|      9|                } = &existing.kind
  510|       |            {
  511|      9|                match (existing_align, new_align) {
  512|      0|                    (Some(a), Some(b)) if a != b => {
  513|      0|                        return Err(SymbolTableError::InvalidRedefinition {
  514|      0|                            name,
  515|      0|                            existing: existing_ref,
  516|      0|                        });
  517|       |                    }
  518|      0|                    (None, Some(b)) => {
  519|       |                        // Inherit alignment from new declaration
  520|      0|                        if let SymbolKind::Variable { alignment, .. } = &mut existing.kind {
  521|      0|                            *alignment = Some(*b);
  522|      0|                        }
  523|       |                    }
  524|      9|                    _ => {}
  525|       |                }
  526|     18|            }
  527|       |
  528|       |            // Apply C11 merging rules
  529|     27|            match (existing.def_state, new_entry.def_state) {
  530|       |                (DefinitionState::Defined, DefinitionState::Defined) => {
  531|       |                    // Multiple actual definitions - error

                                         ^0
  533|      2|                    return Err(SymbolTableError::InvalidRedefinition {
  534|      2|                        name,
  535|      2|                        existing: existing_ref,
  536|      2|                    });
  537|       |                }
  538|       |
  539|       |                (DefinitionState::Defined, _) => {
  540|       |                    // Already defined, ignore new declaration/tentative definition
  541|      1|                    debug!("Ignoring redundant declaration for already-defined '{}'", name);

  542|       |                }
  543|       |

  560|       |                | (DefinitionState::DeclaredOnly, DefinitionState::DeclaredOnly) => {

  722|     82|    fn compute_record_layout(&mut self, members: &[StructMember], is_union: bool) -> Result<TypeLayout, SemanticError> {
  723|     82|        let mut max_align = 1;
  724|     82|        let mut current_size = 0;
  725|     82|        let mut field_layouts = Vec::with_capacity(members.len());
  726|       |        // For C11 6.7.2.1p18 flexible array check:
  727|       |        // "the last element of a structure with more than one named member may have an incomplete array type"
  728|       |        // But incomplete array types are NOT allowed in unions.
  729|       |        // We will check validity as we iterate.
  730|       |        // Note: The count of members might include anonymous struct/union members which are technically members.
  731|       |
  732|     82|        let member_count = members.len();
  733|       |
  734|    139|        for (i, member) in members.iter().enumerate() {
                                         ^82     ^82    ^82
  735|    139|            let member_ty = member.member_type.ty();
  736|       |
  737|       |            // Special handling for flexible array member (FAM)
  738|       |            // Need to check if it is incomplete array
  739|       |            // We can't use is_complete because that recurses. We check TypeKind directly.
  740|    139|            let is_incomplete_or_vla_array = if member_ty.is_inline_array() {
  741|      6|                false // inline array always has len
  742|       |            } else {
  743|    130|                matches!(
  744|    133|                    self.get(member_ty).kind,
  745|       |                    TypeKind::Array {
  746|       |                        size: ArraySizeType::Incomplete | ArraySizeType::Variable(_),
  747|       |                        ..
  748|       |                    }
  749|       |                )
  750|       |            };
  751|       |
  752|    139|            if is_incomplete_or_vla_array {
  753|      3|                if is_union {
  754|       |                    // Incomplete or VLA types not allowed in union
  755|      1|                    return Err(SemanticError::UnsupportedFeature {
  756|      1|                        feature: "incomplete/VLA array in union".to_string(),
  757|      1|                        span: member.span,
  758|      1|                    });
  759|      2|                }
  760|       |
  761|       |                // Must be last member
  762|      2|                if i != member_count - 1 {
  763|      1|                    return Err(SemanticError::FlexibleArrayNotLast { span: member.span });
  764|      1|                }
  765|       |
  766|       |                // Must have at least one other named member.
  767|       |                // Or rather, "structure with more than one named member".
  768|       |                // If this is the only member, it's invalid.
  769|      1|                if member_count < 2 {
  770|      0|                    return Err(SemanticError::FlexibleArrayInEmptyStruct { span: member.span });
  771|      1|                }
  772|       |
  773|       |                // If valid FAM:
  774|       |                // Size of structure is as if FAM was omitted.
  775|       |                // But we must respect its alignment for the struct's alignment.
  776|       |                // We need to get the element type to find alignment.
  777|      1|                let elem_ty = match &self.get(member_ty).kind {
  778|      1|                    TypeKind::Array { element_type, .. } => *element_type,
  779|      0|                    _ => unreachable!(),
  780|       |                };
  781|      1|                let elem_layout = self.ensure_layout(elem_ty)?;
                                                                           ^0
  782|       |
  783|      1|                max_align = max_align.max(elem_layout.alignment);
  784|       |
  785|       |                // FAM has size 0 for layout purposes of the struct size,
  786|       |                // but its offset is where it would start.
  787|       |                // The standard says: "size of the structure is as if the flexible array member were omitted"
  788|       |                // This means current_size stays as is (after padding for alignment of FAM? No, omitted means omitted).
  789|       |                // "except that it may have more trailing padding than the omission would imply"
  790|       |                // Usually this is interpreted as: sizeof(struct) = max(sizeof(struct_without_fam), offsetof(fam)).
  791|       |                // Or simply: layout the FAM, but don't increment current_size by its size (which is unknown/0).
  792|       |                // But we might need to add padding to current_size to reach FAM alignment?
  793|       |                // "as if the flexible array member were omitted" implies we don't even add padding for it?
  794|       |                // BUT "except that it may have more trailing padding".
  795|       |                // Most compilers align the end of the struct to the alignment of the FAM.
  796|       |
  797|       |                // Let's compute offset.
  798|      1|                let offset = (current_size + elem_layout.alignment - 1) & !(elem_layout.alignment - 1);
  799|      1|                field_layouts.push(FieldLayout { offset });
  800|       |
  801|       |                // We do NOT update current_size with FAM size (which is effectively 0 or variable).
  802|       |                // But we might update current_size to offset?
  803|       |                // GCC: sizeof(struct { int x; int y[]; }) == 4.
  804|       |                //      sizeof(struct { char c; int y[]; }) == 4 (aligned to 4).
  805|       |                // So we do align current_size.
  806|      1|                current_size = offset;
  807|       |
  808|      1|                continue;
  809|    136|            }
  810|       |
  811|    136|            let layout = self.ensure_layout(member_ty)?;
                                                                    ^0
  812|    136|            let mut member_align = layout.alignment;
  813|    136|            if let Some(req_align) = member.alignment {
                                      ^5
  814|      5|                member_align = member_align.max(req_align as u16);
  815|    131|            }
  816|    136|            max_align = max_align.max(member_align);
  817|       |
  818|    136|            if is_union {
  819|     13|                current_size = current_size.max(layout.size);
  820|     13|                field_layouts.push(FieldLayout { offset: 0 });
  821|    123|            } else {
  822|    123|                // Align current_size to member's alignment to find its offset
  823|    123|                let offset = (current_size + member_align - 1) & !(member_align - 1);
  824|    123|                field_layouts.push(FieldLayout { offset });
  825|    123|                current_size = offset + layout.size;
  826|    123|            }
  827|       |        }
  828|       |
  829|       |        // Final size is padded to the record's max alignment
  830|     80|        let final_size = (current_size + max_align - 1) & !(max_align - 1);
  831|       |
  832|     80|        Ok(TypeLayout {
  833|     80|            size: final_size,
  834|     80|            alignment: max_align,
  835|     80|            kind: LayoutKind::Record {
  836|     80|                fields: field_layouts,
  837|     80|                is_union,
  838|     80|            },
  839|     80|        })
  840|     82|    }

  842|    543|    pub(crate) fn decay(&mut self, qt: QualType, ptr_qualifiers: TypeQualifiers) -> QualType {
  843|    543|        let kind = self.get(qt.ty()).kind.clone();

  845|     55|            TypeKind::Array { element_type, .. } => {
  846|       |                // Correct logic: Array of T decays to Pointer to T.
  847|       |                // Qualifiers on Array apply to the element in the resulting pointer type.
  848|     55|                let elem_qt = QualType::new(element_type, qt.qualifiers());
  849|     55|                let ptr = self.pointer_to(elem_qt);
  850|       |                // Apply the extracted pointer qualifiers (e.g. from static/const inside [])
  851|     55|                QualType::new(ptr, ptr_qualifiers)
  852|       |            }
  853|       |            TypeKind::Function { .. } => {
  854|     10|                let ptr = self.pointer_to(qt);
  855|     10|                QualType::new(ptr, ptr_qualifiers)
  856|       |            }
  857|    478|            _ => qt,
  858|       |        }
  859|    543|    }

 1039|    377|    pub(crate) fn is_complete(&self, ty: TypeRef) -> bool {
 1040|    377|        if ty.is_inline_pointer() {
 1041|     37|            return true;
 1042|    340|        }
 1043|    340|        if ty.is_inline_array() {
 1044|       |            // Array is complete if element is complete
 1045|       |            // But strict C says array valid if element type is complete (except local VLA which is complete at runtime allocation point?)
 1046|       |            // Here we just check element kind.
 1047|     16|            let elem = self.reconstruct_element(ty);
 1048|     16|            return self.is_complete(elem);
 1049|    324|        }

  230|       |/// Opaque reference to a canonical type.
  231|       |/// Internally index + 1 (NonZeroU32 for niche optimization).
  232|       |#[derive(Copy, Clone, Debug, PartialEq, Eq, Hash, Serialize)]
  233|       |#[repr(transparent)]
  234|       |pub struct TypeRef(NonZeroU32);
  235|       |
  236|       |impl TypeRef {
  237|       |    // Layout:
  238|       |    // bit  0..=17  (18 bit)  BASE INDEX
  239|       |    // bit 18..=20  (3 bit)   TYPE CLASS
  240|       |    // bit 21..=22  (2 bit)   POINTER DEPTH (0..3)
  241|       |    // bit 23..=27  (5 bit)   ARRAY LEN INLINE (0..31)
  242|       |
  243|       |    const BASE_BITS: u32 = 18;
  244|       |    const CLASS_BITS: u32 = 3;
  245|       |    const PTR_BITS: u32 = 2;
  246|       |    const ARR_BITS: u32 = 5;
  247|       |
  248|       |    const BASE_SHIFT: u32 = 0;
  249|       |    const CLASS_SHIFT: u32 = Self::BASE_BITS;
  250|       |    const PTR_SHIFT: u32 = Self::CLASS_SHIFT + Self::CLASS_BITS;
  251|       |    const ARR_SHIFT: u32 = Self::PTR_SHIFT + Self::PTR_BITS;
  252|       |
  253|       |    const BASE_MASK: u32 = (1 << Self::BASE_BITS) - 1;
  254|       |    const CLASS_MASK: u32 = (1 << Self::CLASS_BITS) - 1;
  255|       |    const PTR_MASK: u32 = (1 << Self::PTR_BITS) - 1;
  256|       |    const ARR_MASK: u32 = (1 << Self::ARR_BITS) - 1;
  257|       |
  258|       |    #[inline]
  259|  10.4k|    pub(crate) fn new(base_index: u32, class: TypeClass, ptr_depth: u8, arr_len: u32) -> Option<Self> {
  260|  10.4k|        if base_index == 0 || base_index > Self::BASE_MASK {
  261|      0|            return None; // Base index must be non-zero and fit in 18 bits
  262|  10.4k|        }
  263|  10.4k|        if ptr_depth as u32 > Self::PTR_MASK {
  264|      1|            return None;
  265|  10.4k|        }
  266|  10.4k|        if arr_len > Self::ARR_MASK {
  267|      1|            return None;
  268|  10.4k|        }
  269|       |
  270|       |        // Validate combinations
  271|  10.4k|        match class {
  272|       |            TypeClass::Builtin => {
  273|  8.41k|                if ptr_depth != 0 || arr_len != 0 {
                                                   ^8.40k
  274|      1|                    return None;
  275|  8.40k|                }
  276|       |            }
  277|       |            TypeClass::Pointer => {
  278|    837|                if arr_len != 0 {
  279|      1|                    return None;
  280|    836|                }
  281|       |                // Pointer depth 0 means "Registry Pointer" (valid)
  282|       |                // Pointer depth 1..3 means "Inline Pointer" (valid)
  283|       |            }
  284|       |            TypeClass::Array => {
  285|       |                // Array len 0 means "Registry Array" (valid)
  286|       |                // Array len 1..31 means "Inline Array" (valid)
  287|    455|                if ptr_depth != 0 {
  288|      1|                    return None;
  289|    454|                }
  290|       |            }
  291|       |            TypeClass::Function | TypeClass::Record | TypeClass::Enum | TypeClass::Typedef | TypeClass::Complex => {
  292|    775|                if ptr_depth != 0 || arr_len != 0 {
  293|      0|                    return None;
  294|    775|                }
  295|       |            }
  296|       |        }
  297|       |
  298|  10.4k|        let mut raw = 0u32;
  299|  10.4k|        raw |= base_index & Self::BASE_MASK;
  300|  10.4k|        raw |= (class as u32) << Self::CLASS_SHIFT;
  301|  10.4k|        raw |= (ptr_depth as u32) << Self::PTR_SHIFT;
  302|  10.4k|        raw |= (arr_len) << Self::ARR_SHIFT;
  303|       |
  304|  10.4k|        NonZeroU32::new(raw).map(TypeRef)
  305|  10.4k|    }
